ref.mixed-citation: Toward the end of his life, Miller publishedThe Paradox of Cause(:Norton,1978), hereafter cited in text as PC. Shortly after his death, Miller's 1922 Harvard dissertation and subsequent notes were published as The Definition of the Thing with Some Notes on Language (:Norton,1980), hereafter cited in text as DT. This was quickly followed by The Philosophy of History with Reflections and Aphorisms (:Norton,1981), hereafter cited in text as as PH; by The Midworld of Symbols and Functioning Objects (:Norton,1982), hereafter cited in text as MS; and by In Defense of the Psychological (:Norton,1983), hereafter cited in text as DP. I will refer to Miller's few published and many unpublished essays only as they are relevant to my argument, but they are all available, along with the remainder of Miller's unfinished works and notes, at the Miller Archives at Williams College. Here, I will refer to papers from the Miller Archives as the “Miller Papers,” hereafter cited in text as MP, followed by box and folder number. Only box 55 of these papers will be cited separately, as the “Papers and Letters of John William Miller,” complied by Eugene Miller (cited in text as PL). As well, see the collection by John William Miller , The Task of Criticism: Essays on Philosophy, History, and Community , ed. and introduction Joseph P. Fell , Vincent Colapietro , and Michael J. McGandy (:Norton,2005). For secondary literature, see Joseph P. Fell , ed., The Philosophy of John William Miller (:Bucknell UP,1990). For book-length studies devoted to Miller , see Stephen Tyman , Descrying the Ideal: The Philosophy of John William Miller (:Southern Illinois UP,1993); Vincent Colapietro , Fateful Shapes of Human Freedom: John William Miller and the Crises of Modernity (:Vanderbilt UP,2003); and Michael J. McGandy , The Active Life: Miller's Metaphysics of Democracy (:State U of New York P,2005).

As McGandy underscores, functioning objects do not merely represent actions or environments, nor are they just signs indicative of content or independent states of be-ing. McGandy provides a thorough examination of the context of symbolic functioning, as well as a close comparison of signs and symbols (Active Lifechap. 3). Tyman explains the symbolic character of functioning objects insofar as “all significance is mediated through them” (Descrying the Ideal 104). Colapietro's discussion of symbolic action runs throughout his monograph on Miller (Fateful Shapes). His handling of the way the body functions as a symbol occurs in Chapter 3.

In 1960 Miller writes, for example: “We need not take too seriously the current objections to metaphysics…. We like to inhabit a world, and indeed are sure to do so if we enjoy so much as a local habituation and a name.” See“Afterword: The Ahistoric and the Historic,”rpt. in The Task of Criticism ,183–202. Miller also writes: “The anti-metaphysics of our day masquerades as an assault on totality; what it isequallyattacking is presence, the other side of totality. The center of this obscurantism is the repudiation of the act” (MS 13). And further: “The aversion to ‘metaphysics’ is the sign of an inability to identify the basis both of the distinctions [between patterns and atomicity] and of their rejection” (PH128).
The history and scope of the “metacritical” position is the subject ofMetacritique: The Linguistic Assault on German Idealism, ed. and trans. Jere Paul Surber (:Humanity Books,2001).

Miller also calls his “historical idealism” a “naturalist idealism” and a “concretism” in Definition of the Thing (149). In a short piece for theWilliams Alumni Review, Fell stresses the fact that Miller rejects the premise of any extant distinction between idealism and realism. Joseph P. Fell ,“The Philosopher of Elm Street,”
Williams Alumni Review
102.4(2008):9–12. Fell extends that explanation in “Miller: The Man and His Philosophy,” in Philosophy of John William Miller (21–31), where he also coins the terms “philosophy of the act.” Fell goes on to coin and utilize the term “actualism.” Colapietro argues that Miller's position can be rightly called a “historicist humanism,” (Fateful Shapes 168). Both he and McGandy also adopt the term “actualism,” following Fell.
See Fell ( Philosophy of John William Miller ;“Philosopher of Elm Street”), as cited in Note 6.

In the following, I will argue that Miller's reception of Kant links him to more familiar late modern initiatives. While a point-by-point survey of these continuities is beyond the scope of this essay, one representative comparison would juxtapose Miller's midworld of functioning objects to Gilles Deleuze's exploration of the “virtual,” and likewise to the “sensible deformations” of form. Deleuze often depicts the sensible appearance outside of which no form can be given; see, for example, Gilles Deleuze , Difference and Repetition , trans. Paul Patton (:Columbia UP,1995).

Charles Taylor can be credited for bringing the designation of the “expressive theory of meaning” to contemporary attention. Taylor's prime examples of expressive theorists are Hamann, Herder, and Humboldt; Wittgenstein is their later modern inheritor. See Charles Taylor , Human Agency and Language ,Philosophical Papers, Vol.1(:Cambridge UP,1985); as well as Taylor 's“The Importance of Herder,”
Isaiah Berlin: A Celebration , ed. Edna Ullmann-Margalit and Avishai Margalit (:U of Chicago P,1991).

The quote, of course, is a paraphrase of Wittgenstein 's famous assertion in the Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus ,5.6, ed. A. J. Ayer , trans. D. F. Pears and B. F. McGuin ness (:Routledge & Kegan Paul,1961). Compare this to Miller's claim that “we are in league with meanings in ourselves that our own experience has not produced. We do not, therefore, know what our words mean unless we search out those experiences of others by which they have come to mean what they now mean to us” (PH 187).

McGandy illustrates how all expressive activity is a “historical achievement” ( Active Life
76–77). Colapietro makes essentially the same point, albeit with reversed emphasis ( Fateful Shapes
114).

“The act, the person, the here-and-now, the word, appear together…. Space, time, quantity, change, are indeed not cognitive. They are all actual. They are not real; they are not imaginary. Cause is not a presupposition imposed on events lacking a causal order. Any identified event is a consequence of an active control, if only of ‘looking’; where some limitation of appearance is constitutional to the looking” (MS 102).

See Miller 's“For Idealism,”
Journal of Speculative Philosophy
1.4(1987):260–69. Tyman analyzes Millerian categories inDescrying the Ideal(127).

Herder 's linguistic initiative begins with the “Treatise on the Origin of Language” and is followed by several related works, available in Johann Gottfried von Herder ,Philosophical Writings, trans. Michael N. Forster (:Cambridge UP,2002). A later formulation may be found in Herder , Against Pure Reason: Writings on religion, Language, and History , trans., ed., and introduction Marcia Bunge (:Fortress,1993). Herder's lifelong occupation with linguistic and, in some cases, metacritical analyses may be surveyed in his complete works:Werke in zehn Bänden(:Deutsche Klassiker Verlag,1985). I analyze Herder's (and Hamann's) linguistic critique of Kant in Katie Terezakis , The Immanent Word: The Turn to Language in German Philosophy
1759–1801(:Routledge,2007).

English translations of Hamann 's “The Metacritique of the Purism of Reason” are available in Gwen Griffith Dickson'sJohann Georg Hamann's Relational Metacriticism(:Walter de Gruyter,1995); and in Kenneth Haynes 's Hamann: Writings on Philosophy and Language (:Cambridge UP,2007). The German edition is available in Hamann 's Sämtliche Werke , Historisch-Kritische Ausgabe , ed. Josef Nadler (:Herder Verlag,1949–1957), Vol.3,283–89.
See Hamann 's“Metacritique of the Purism of Reason.”For an elaboration of the metacritical position, see Surber ( Metacritique: The Linguistic Assault ).

Kant distinguishes between sensibility and intuition, the “two fundamental sources in the mind,” at A50/B74. See Immanuel Kant , Critique of Pure Reason , trans. and ed. Paul Guyer and Allen W. Wood (:Cambridge UP,1998),193. Hamann is the first (though clearly not the last) to issue this charge against Kant, yet from his day until the present, Hamann is insufficiently credited for introducing the criticism. This is probably, or at least in part, because Hamann's notoriously obscure writing style, along with his constant references to his own religious enthusiasm (orSchwärmeri), tend to cloak his arguments in a bewildering form.

Although Hamann is not always credited with inaugurating the metacritical position, compelling defenses of his influence, in addition to the works already cited by Charles Taylor and Jere Paul Surber , have been made by Isaiah Berlin , in Three Critics of the Enlightenment: Vico, Hamann, Herder (:Princeton UP,2000); in The Roots of Romanticism (:Princeton UP,1999); and in “The Counter-Enlightenment,” Against the Current (:Penguin,1979),162–87; and by Fredrick C. Beiser , inThe Fate of Reason(:Harvard UP,1987); and by John H. Zammito , in The Genesis of Kant's Critique of Judgment (:U of Chicago P,1992).

Hegel on Hamann, trans. and introduction by Lisa Marie Anderson (:Northwestern UP,2008). Anderson's introduction examines Hegel's utilization of Hamannian initiatives, as well as his perplexing equivocation about their importance.
Colapietro has made a strong case for understanding Miller as an inheritor of the overtly Hegelian dialectic (Fateful Shapes 41–46).

See also “Papers and Letters” (box 55:514). Miller also asserts that Ralph Waldo Emerson “far surpasses Hegel in his grasp of the ontological status of the actual. In the end Hegel did not make good on his claim that he found the energy internal to the spectacle….Geistis not a local control.” John William Miller, “The Owl,” Transactions of the Charles S. Pierce Society

In terms of tracing the subsidiary modes of idealism and its critics, Colapietro provides a valuable comparison of pragmatism and idealism inFateful Shapes(chap. 3); Tyman measures Miller's project against those of Husserl, Heidegger, Nietzsche, Foucault, Merleau-Ponty, Ricoeur, and Gadamer throughoutDescrying the Ideal, and McGandy forcefully situates Miller vis-à-vis the American anti-metaphysical and anti-authoritarian tradition inActive Life(chap. 1).

The Miller Archives at Williams College contain Miller's lecture notes on most every major (and minor) philosophical initiative from the eighteenth century to the twentieth, as well as his notes on courses devoted to ancient philosophy and to discrete philosophical disciplines such as logic and aesthetics, wherein the thoughts of various idealists and their critics are also treated.

Tyman lays essential groundwork for establishing both Miller's idealist inheritance and his affinities with the heirs of that tradition in both hermeneutic and deconstructive milieus (Descrying the Ideal). Colapietro accounts for Miller's American and pragmatic context, including a careful examination of Miller's affinity with William James and Henry David Thoreau. Colapietro also deals with Miller's engagement with German idealism, and goes on to fruitfully compare Miller with Kierkegaard, Husserl, Heidegger, Sartre, Derrida, Judith Butler, and Gianni Vattimo (Fateful Shapes).

Though the concept exists in various works, I take the term “transcendental-empirical hybrid” from Cristina Lafont, who uses it to describe the linguistic enterprise of Hamann, Herder, Humboldt, and their later modern successors. Cristina Lafont , The Linguistic Turn in Hermeneutic Philosophy , trans. José Medina (:MIT P,1999).

See also: “The defect of Kant's categories occurs in the assumption that they are properties of pure reason, that is, that they are laws of order, of order without specific focus. Every category has a focus, such as a yardstick or a clock, a thermometer, etc.” (MS 33–34).

McGandy ( Active Life
72) draws out the distinction between “psychological” and “ontological” actions: ontological action is free, creative, and responsible, whereas psychological action is determined or causally bound. To McGandy's helpful partition, I add that utterance, in its form as a declaration or proposition of natural language, merits both the free ontological and the determined psychological delineation.

Miller writes: “Language of all sorts is not themeansof communication, but theactualityof communication” (DT 189). Also: “The word must be its own warrant” (DP 161). See too: “Every specific act emerges from a matrix of commitment, a commitment necessary in principle but accidental in content” (PH 33). Hamann makes essentially the same point in his “Metacritique of the Purism of Reason.” I examine the implications of this insight in Terezakis,Immanent Wordas well as in Terezakis, “Language and Immanence in Hamann,” Graduate Faculty Philosophy Journal

Paradox of Cause. Miller also refers to this conclusion inMidworld of Symbols(107), associating the pure “causality” that paradoxically cannot explain any particular event with notions of God or Nature. Fell describes the upshot of the paradox of cause (Philosophy of John William Miller 23). Fell concludes: “Subjective purposes and objective nature are mutually implicative, or their relation is ‘dialectical.’”

“I can make no object of nature, or of myself, or of another person. Indeed, all these distinctions are immediate and linguistic. They occur functionally, not in passive perception, not as accidents but as structure…. There is no object without a word for object…. I [must] look for the origin of language in act and in functioning” (MS74–75).

Kant distinguishes between the constitutive and the regulative in theCritique of Pure ReasonA178/B221-A181/B224. Constitutive principles bring the existence of appearances under rulesa priori“so that the rule of [a thing's] synthesis at the same time yields this intuitiona prioriin every empirical example.” The axioms of intuition and the anticipations of perception are constitutive, whereas ideas about the origin or telos of the cosmos are regulative. The principles of reason are regulative, in that they allow us to avoid speculative regress without “supplying a concept” or giving a proof for the principle posited (compare A508/B536ff). Quotations from the firstCritiqueare taken from the Paul Guyer and Allen W. Wood edition and translation (:Cambridge UP,1998).

In his examination of Miller'sThe Philosophy of HistoryandIn Defense of the Psychological, McGandy (Active Life 39) looks closely at Miller's use of the notion of the “constitutional.” Though anything constitutional is, as Miller says “synonymous with structure,” McGandy discerns two distinct senses of constitutionality in Miller's thinking: constitutionality as the necessary, or formal and non-episodic; and constitutionality as the constructive (i.e., actively “constituting”) element of a thing. In this essay, I am focusing on Miller's appropriation and transformation of the Kantian “constitutive” (and regulative), so this distinction is not essential to my argument, though it is consistent with it.

The “Transcendental Dialectic” describes in scrupulous detail why there can be no justification for taking a regulative idea outside of its appropriate bounds for constitutive application. In terms of establishing the “limits of reason,” this proof may be Kant's most crucial innovation.
See myImmanent Word, chap. 4. See also Zammito ( Genesis ).

Kant writes: “[R]eason does not contest the possibility or actuality of these ideas [miracles, mysteries, or grace],” but he insists that we cannot claim knowledge of the “inscrutable field of the supernatural” (Religion96, 6: 52).

Kant mentions the need, on behalf of the immature mind, to preserve religion's “rational seed” within a mythic shell. “What is the basis of alienation? … [T]he mystery of the material world, a world I never made…. Mrs. Job had an answer too; it was ‘Curse God and die.’ Why not, on the premises? She was ‘alienated’” (MS 150).

Compare John T. Sanders 's“Political Authority,”
Monist
66.4(1983):545–56: “‘Natural’ authority entails the propriety of counsel or advice or even command in some area of knowledge or activity. Where it is command that is appropriate, this is because the action in question ‘belongs,’ in some sense, to the bearer of authority. The action is ‘his’ or ‘hers’ to take” (549). And: “What is crucial about this acknowledgment, however, is that ‘natural’ authority so construed is necessarily a voluntary matter. Peoplediscoversuch authority in others, or think that they do, and act in accord with their belief in it” (551).

I am indebted to David Suits for the formulation “authority is procuring organization.” Suits (in a personal correspondence) bases his description on the work of the nineteenth-century legal theorist, John Austin, particularly hisThe Province of Jurisprudence Determined(:Hackett,1998), which deals in part with legal systems as organizations of commands.

Colapietro examines the features of Miller's “constitutional conflicts” at several points ( Fateful Shapes , see, e.g.,64–65,81). Colapietro also quotes this sentence of Miller's as a case in point: “[In] philosophy … every controlling term means what it has come to mean in the controversies which alone give it authority” (PC 92).

“Any act proposing to be authoritative … must invoke the inherent command of some utterance, of an actuality that regulates and enforces…. Persons have been confident about themselves insofar as they have seen themselves allied with an infinity, a universal, a divinity” (MS123–24).

Miller describes the reification of a universal as “demonry” in his “Afterword: The Ahistoric and The Historic” (rept. inThe Task of Criticism,183–202). McGandy provides an analysis of “Fate, Demonry, and Nemesis” ( Active Life , chap. 4.2). McGandy points out that Miller is drawing from Paul Tillich's definition of demonry inSystematic Theology: Life and the SpiritandSystematic Theology: History and Kingdom of God, Vol.3, parts 4 and 5 (:U of Chicago P,1963).
